questiontext.text:
The inverse of a \(3\times 3\) matrix – determinant method

This method which employs determinants, is of importance from a theoretical perspective. The numerical computations involved are too heavy for matrices of higher order than \(3\times 3\) and in such cases the Gauss elimination approach is preferred. 

To obtain \(A^{-1}\) using the determinant approach the steps in the following keypoint are followed:

Key Point

Matrix Inverse – the Determinant Method

Given a square matrix \(A\), we first calculate \(|A|\). If \(|A|=0\) then \(A^{-1}\) does not exist. 

If \(|A|\neq 0\) we can proceed to find the inverse matrix, as follows:

  • Replace each element of \(A\) by its cofactor
  • Transpose the result to form the adjoint matrix, denoted by \(\mathrm{adj}(A)\)
  • Then calculate \(A^{-1}=\frac{1}{|A|}\mathrm{adj}(A)\).
